committeeComposition.paragraph: Again, it is different in virtually every marketplace. Some markets' financials tend to be more dominated than the commodity and natural and softs markets. But yet the markets we live in today are majority automated and increasingly algorithmic. I mean, the day of the manual trading is passing with the day of the trading floor. And we have to accept that markets are becoming digital in the same way the rest of our world is becoming digital, and they are becoming increasingly automated and increasingly algorithmic. That is the world we heading toward, and that is why, as an agency, we need to be up to that challenge. We need to be as digital as these markets.
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Young
committeeComposition.paragraph: It reminds me of a line from a Pink Floyd song: Welcome to the Machine.
I yield.
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Aderholt
committeeComposition.paragraph: Ms. DeLauro.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

Chairman Giancarlo, you convened a meeting of the CFTC on February 28. It was with the SEC Chairman Clayton, SEC Commissioner Peirce, CFTC Commissioner Quintenz, and the staff from both the CFTC and the SEC. This is a tweet from your February 27 gathering at 9:18 p.m., and it reads: Earlier today, at CFTC, staff at CFTC, Quintenz, and I hosted Chairman Clayton and SEC colleagues to discuss better harmonizing Dodd- Frank regs and rules. We are off to a great start.

This was not a public meeting, but one that was behind closed doors and one among only Republican members of both Commissions as I understand it. It is troubling, but even more troubling than the partisanship of the meeting is the fact that the meeting appeared to potentially violate the Government in the Sunshine Act, and you know that act. It may require that, for the CFTC in its current form, you have got two of three members of the CFTC meeting, that it must be open to the public unless an exemption applies. It appears to me, based on your tweet, discussing better harmonization of Dodd-Frank regulations and the rules involve policy discussions that, to my mind, should have been open to the public. So let me run down just a few questions for which I was just looking for a yes-or-no answer.
Did the information shared during the meeting relate to national defense?
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: No.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Was the meeting related solely to internal personnel rules and practices?
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: The meeting was a briefing by staffs of the two agencies on progress that had or had not been made in the-- statutorily required harmonization of Dodd-Frank rules between the two agencies.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Did the meeting have any discussion of the current state of looking at what is going on with the unraveling of the Dodd-Frank regulations?
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: No.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Was the meeting related to accusing a person of a crime?
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: No.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Was the meeting related to information where disclosure would constitute a breach of privacy?
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: No.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Was the meeting related to investigatory records where the information would harm the proceedings?
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: You know, can I say what the meeting was?
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Sure.
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: The meeting was a briefing by staffs that had worked on harmonization efforts as statutorily required. And the meeting was overseen by the Office of General Counsel to make sure that it did not breach the--what is called regulation in the Sunshine Act.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Was the meeting related to information which would lead to financial speculation or endanger the stability of any financial institution?
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: The meeting did not concern any particular financial institution.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Was the meeting related to the agencies participation in legal proceedings?
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: You know, I am almost uncomfortable calling it a meeting. It was a briefing. And no legal proceedings were discussed.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Why then was the meeting not open to the public when that is something that is required and you are talking about, as you said, the harmonization of Dodd-Frank? And making it such a partisan effort----
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: It is not a partisan effort, first of all, because any rulemaking that would come out of this would have to go through the Administrative Procedure Act. My fellow Democratic Commission was briefed on all the issues discussed at the meeting in advance of the meeting.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Why wasn't----
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: The harmonization efforts are Chairman-led efforts at both the SEC and the CFTC. So Chairman Massad never involved me in any----
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: I am not asking about Chairman Massad's----
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: Of course. But it is a Chairman-led effort, and the staff was briefing us on progress that had been made so we could get up to speed when our predecessors left the agencies and to see what needs to be done going forward.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: I don't know what your general counsel said, but as I understand the Sunshine Act requires that CFTC--when two of the members of the CFTC meet, it must be open to the public, unless an exemption applies.
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: And we were assured that an exemption applied for briefings. In fact, meetings take place routinely at the agency where staff brief Commissioners, and those meetings are closed to the public.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: What was the exemption? What is the nature of the exemption?
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Giancarlo
committeeComposition.paragraph: It is nondeliberation of Commission matters. It was a briefing only; it was a one-way information flow.
committeeComposition.speaker: Ms. DeLauro
committeeComposition.paragraph: Well, thank you. Thank you for the clarification of that, but I just think when we are talking about these critical issues these days, it would be good to have the transparency that we have so lacked in the past with regard to so many of the these critically important areas.
Thank you.
committeeComposition.speaker: Mr. Aderholt
committeeComposition.paragraph: Thank you, Ms. DeLauro.

Mr. Chairman, thank you for being here. I think we had a good hearing today to discuss some of these issues and bring up some issues that the members of this subcommittee feel are important. Thank you for sharing and bringing us up to date. And we look forward as we continue on with the fiscal year 2019 appropriation bill that affects your agency. So we look forward to working with you, and thank you for your service.
And the hearing is adjourned.
Thursday, March 15, 2018.
